arm_group.description: preterm infants who received poractantalfa for respiratory distress syndrome
preterm infants who received beractant for respiratory distress syndrome
Preterm infants without respiratory distress syndrome

brief_summary.textblock:
Exogenous bolus surfactant administration may affect hemodynamic parameters and peripheral
      perfusion. Surfactant therapy is commonly used for respiratory distress syndrome in
      premature infants, which is also associated with inflammation. There are different types and
      doses of surfactant preparations available. With the help of new generation monitors,
      changes in peripheral perfusion and transcutaneous CO, a marker of inflammation, may be
      demonstrated.

clinical_study.brief_title: Effects of Bolus Surfactant Therapy on Peripheral Perfusion Index and Tissue Carbon Monoxide

detailed_description.textblock:
Preterm infants with severe Respiratory Distress Syndrome (study group) were compared to
      preterm infants without Respiratory Distress Syndrome(control group). Infants in the study
      group were randomized to receive either poractantalfa or beractant.

      Perfusion index (PI) and transcutaneous CO (TCO) values were measured before (Tp) and 0
      (T0), 5 (T5), 30 (T30), 60 (T60), 360 (T360) minutes after surfactant administration in the
      first six hours of life.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Gestational age between 26 and 36 weeks

          -  intubated for respiratory distress syndrome

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  cardiac defects,

          -  hemodynamically significant patent ductusarteriosus,

          -  congenital pneumonia,

          -  early sepsis

          -  unstable infants in need of inotropic support.

intervention.description: Preparations of poractantalfa (Curosurf, 200 mg/kg) (n = 15) or beractant (Survanta, 100 mg/kg) (n = 15) were administered in a consecutive randomized manner within the first 6 h of life. During the procedure, the tube was disconnected from the ventilator. The patient's head was held in a neutral position and surfactant preparations were given in two bolus fractions. Manual ventilation was given for 2 min after each dose. After the second dose, the endotracheal tube was reconnected and the physician (D.T.) observed the infant for 30-60 s until the oxygen saturation reached > 90% on pulse oximetry. Thereafter, the peak inspiratory pressure of the 6 ventilator was reduced by 1-2 mmH2O.

facility.name: Ege University Children's Hospital Neonatal Intesive Care Unit

clinical_study.official_title: Effects of Bolus Surfactant Therapy on Serial Peripheral Perfusion Index and Tissue Carbon Monoxide Measurements in Preterm Infants With Severe Respiratory Distress Syndrome

overall_official.affiliation: Ege University Faculty of Medicine, Department of Pediatrics, Division of Neonatology

primary_outcome.description: PI values were measured before (Tp) and 0 (T0), 5 (T5), 30 (T30), 60 (T60), 360 (T360) minutes after surfactant administration in the first six hours of life.
primary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline in perfusion index (PI)at 6 hours
primary_outcome.time_frame: before (Tp) and 0 (T0), 5 (T5), 30 (T30), 60 (T60), 360 (T360) minutes after surfactant administration in the first six hours of life

primary_outcome.description: TCO values were measured before (Tp) and 0 (T0), 5 (T5), 30 (T30), 60 (T60), 360 (T360) minutes after surfactant administration in the first six hours of life.
primary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline in transcutaneous carbon monoxide (TCO)at 6 hours
primary_outcome.time_frame: before (Tp) and 0 (T0), 5 (T5), 30 (T30), 60 (T60), 360 (T360) minutes after surfactant administration in the first six hours of life
